subsection.content: A designated officer shall not exercise a power conferred on him by section 27 or 29 without having had regard to the submission (if any) made to him by or on behalf of the officer or other person concerned pursuant to this section.
Where a designated officer exercises a power conferred on him by section 27 or 29, he shall forthwith notify in writing the officer or other person concerned.

A person who is aggrieved by a decision of a designated officer made in the exercise of a power under section 27 or 29 may, within the period of 30 days beginning on the date of the notification of the decision, or such longer period as the Chief Executive may permit, petition the Chief Executive against the decision.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Chief Executive receives a petition under subsection (6), he may, by a letter addressed to a member of the Panel, require the Panel to consider and report to him on the petition, and where the Chief Executive makes such a requirement—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Panel shall comply with the requirement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: before he determines the petition, the Chief Executive shall have regard to the report of the Panel.

subsection.content: In determining a petition under subsection (7) the Chief Executive may, as he thinks fit, confirm, vary or reverse the decision to which the petition relates.

Where pension benefits are cancelled or suspended in accordance with a determination under subsection (2), the Chief Executive may direct that all or any part of the moneys to which the officer or other person concerned would have been entitled by way of pension benefits had he not been convicted and sentenced as specified in section 29(1) or retired as specified in section 29(3) be paid or applied in the same manner and in all respects as provided for in section 28(3), and when the Chief Executive so directs, the moneys to which the direction relates shall be paid or applied in accordance with the direction.

Where a person whose pension benefits have been cancelled or suspended, or have been reduced, in accordance with a determination under subsection (2) receives a free pardon, the pension benefits to which such person would have been entitled had he not been convicted and sentenced as specified in section 29(1) shall be restored to him with retrospective effect as from the date of cancellation, suspension or reduction; but in determining whether any arrears of such pension benefits are payable to such person and in computing the amount thereof account shall be taken of all moneys paid or applied under subsection (9) or, where pension benefits have been reduced, paid as reduced pension benefits.

Where a person whose pension benefits have been cancelled or suspended, or have been reduced, in accordance with a determination under subsection (2), has served any sentence of imprisonment imposed on conviction, the Chief Executive may direct that the pension benefits to which such person would have been entitled had he not been convicted and sentenced as specified in section 29(1) shall be restored to him as from the date on which he completes serving the sentence of imprisonment or any later date as the Chief Executive shall specify in the direction, and where the Chief Executive so directs, the pension benefits to which the direction relates shall be restored in accordance with the direction.

subsection.leadIn: Where a designated officer exercises a power conferred on him by section 27 or 29, the relevant cancellation, suspension or reduction, as the case may be, shall not come into operation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in case no petition is brought under subsection (6) as regards the exercise, until the time for bringing such petition has expired; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in case such a petition is brought, before the petition is either determined or withdrawn.

section.name: s29B
section.heading: Panel

subsection.content: There shall be an advisory panel (in section 29A and this section referred to as the Panel) to perform the functions conferred on it by section 29A and this section.

subsection.leadIn: The Panel shall consist of 3 members of whom—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: 1 shall be appointed by the Chief Executive from amongst—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the judiciary; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the members of the Bar who are not public officers; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the members of the Solicitors’ profession who are not such officers;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: another shall be appointed by the Chief Executive from amongst the justices of the peace who are not public officers; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the remaining member shall be a person, other than a person described in paragraph (a) or (b) or a public officer, appointed by the Chief Executive.

subsection.content: Where the Chief Executive makes a requirement under section 29A(7), the member of the Panel to whom the letter containing the requirement is addressed shall, as soon as may be, convene a meeting of all the members of the Panel to consider and report to the Chief Executive on the petition to which the requirement relates.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: A person appointed to be a member of the Panel shall be appointed for such period (being a period not exceeding 3 years), as shall be specified by the Chief Executive at the time of appointment.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: A member of the Panel may resign his office by letter addressed to the Chief Executive and the resignation shall take effect as on and from the date of the receipt of the letter by the Chief Executive.

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: The Chief Executive may remove from office any member of the Panel who has become incapable through ill-health of effectively performing his duties, or who has committed stated misbehaviour or whose removal appears to the Chief Executive to be necessary for the effective performance by the Panel of its functions.

subsection.content: Sections 42, 48 and 49 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) shall not have effect as regards the Panel or its members.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Pension may be suspended on certain post-retirement employment

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive may direct that any pension granted to a person shall be suspended as from such date as the Chief Executive shall specify if such person has, within 2 years after his retirement and without the prior permission in writing of the Chief Executive—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: entered business on his own account;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: become a partner in a partnership;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: become a director of a company; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: become an employee,

subsection.continued: if the principal part of such business or the business of such partnership or company or of his employment is, in the opinion of the Chief Executive, carried on in Hong Kong, and such direction shall be forthwith notified in writing by the Secretary for the Civil Service to the person concerned.

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may specify a period of more than 2 years for the purposes of subsection (1) where he thinks fit, and such specification shall be forthwith notified in writing by the Secretary for the Civil Service to the person concerned.

A person who is aggrieved by any direction under subsection (1) or any specification under subsection (2) may, within 30 days of the notification to him of the direction or specification or such longer period as the Chief Executive may in any particular case permit, petition the Chief Executive against the direction or specification and the Chief Executive may confirm, vary or reverse the direction or specification as he thinks fit.

Where a person whose pension has been suspended under subsection (1) ceases to be engaged in any of the capacities specified in that subsection, the Chief Executive may, if he is satisfied that the person has so ceased to be engaged, direct that the pension shall be restored to him with retrospective effect as from the date of cesser of the engagement or any later date as the Chief Executive shall specify, and the pension shall be restored accordingly.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Pension benefits not assignable

subsection.leadIn: Save as otherwise provided by the Public Officer (Assignment of Emoluments) Ordinance (Cap. 363), pension benefits granted to an officer shall not be assignable or transferable except for the purpose of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: satisfying (either in whole or in part) a debt due to the Government; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: satisfying an order of any court for the payment of money towards the maintenance of the spouse or former spouse or minor child of the officer,

subsection.continued: and pension benefits shall not be liable to be attached, sequestered or levied upon for or in respect of any claim or debt other than a debt due to the Government.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Where any person to whom pension benefits are granted owes a debt to the Government, subject to paragraph (b), the Director of Accounting Services may apply those benefits, either in whole or in part, for the satisfaction, or partial satisfaction, of the debt.

paragraph.name: b

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a person owes a debt to the Government arising otherwise than on account of tax payable under the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap. 112); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the person has not consented to the exercise, in relation to pension benefits granted to him, of the power conferred on the Director of Accounting Services by this subsection,

paragraph.continued: the amount applied in such exercise shall not, as regards a particular such benefit, exceed an amount equal to 25% of the benefit.

subsection.content: Each of the references in this section to pension benefits shall be construed as including a reference to any increase in the benefits which is for the time being authorized under section 4 of the Pensions (Increase) Ordinance (Cap. 305).

section.name: s31A
section.heading: Operation of section 31
section.content: Section 31, as enacted by section 7(1) of the Pension Benefits (Miscellaneous Amendments) Ordinance 1988 (61 of 1988), shall be deemed to have come into operation on 1 July 1987.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Grant of short service gratuity

subsection.content: If a pension cannot be granted to an officer whose service under the Government is less than the qualifying service specified in section 11 or 12, he shall be granted, on retirement from the public service, a short service gratuity at the prescribed rate in respect of his service. (Amended 4 of 1993 s. 25)
Short service gratuity granted to an officer shall be payable to him as soon as possible after retirement.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Chief Executive’s power to exempt or modify

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may exempt any officer and his dependants from the application of any provisions of this Ordinance and the regulations in any particular case, or may modify the application of any such provisions in any such case in the manner specified by him, where in his opinion inequity results from the application of such provisions; but any such exemption or modification shall not be detrimental to the officer or his dependants and shall be in keeping with the spirit of this Ordinance. (Amended 63 of 1999 s. 3)

No exemption or modification shall be made under subsection (1) unless a draft of it has been laid before and approved by resolution of the Legislative Council, and section 34 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) does not apply in relation to the exemption or modification. (Replaced 4 of 1993 s. 26)

section.name: s34
section.heading: Power to amend Schedule
section.content: The Secretary for the Civil Service may by order published in the Gazette amend the Schedule.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Regulations

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may make regulations providing for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the grant of pension benefits to officers who are transferred to or from service under the Government from or to other public service;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the factor for the computation of pension on retirement and such factor may apply to service before 1 July 1987;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the computation of qualifying service;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the service which may be taken into account as qualifying service or pensionable service, which may include qualifying service or pensionable service prior to 1 July 1987, and for deeming an increase in pensionable service in certain circumstances;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the emoluments which may be taken into account for computing pension benefits;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the determination of highest pensionable emoluments;

paragraph.name: g
h
paragraph.content: the better carrying out of the purpose and provisions of this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), whenever the Chief Executive in Council is satisfied that it is equitable that any regulation made under subsection (1) should have retrospective effect in order to confer a benefit upon or remove a disability attaching to any person that regulation may be given retrospective effect for that purpose.
No regulation given retrospective effect under subsection (2) shall become operative unless it has received the prior approval of the Legislative Council signified by resolution.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Transitional
section.content: Nothing in the Employees’ Compensation (Amendment) (No. 2) Ordinance 2000 (52 of 2000) (the amending Ordinance) shall apply to claims for compensation in respect of accidents occurring before the commencement* of the amending Ordinance, and the provisions in force immediately before the commencement of the amending Ordinance shall continue to apply to such claims as if they had not been amended by the amending Ordinance.
